seg.seg: ... shining, this jewel of a cotton cloth, therefore by the Gautamid queen (is said?) ...
(her) skill(?) has become evident in this cotton cloth. Like an accumulation of lightning,
... a piece of clothing having exceeded human dresses in reﬁnements, it is worthy of gods ...
... it may go well with the tender and gold-colored skin of the Buddha-god the teacher.
... the Śākya queen with the cotton cloth in her hand, having come close to the Buddha-god the teacher, (with) great ...
she says: || In the Kantsakarṣaṃ [tune] || I venerate your total goodness, my lord and son. A (long time) ...
... may they have sons. May they be liberated like me from the hell, from the animals, from the ghosts. 1. || The Buddha(-god the teacher) ...
Then the Gaudamid queen having taken hold with both hands of the gold-colored cotton cloth, with great (respect?) ...
... the new gold-colored jewel of a cotton cloth spun by myself. For the Buddha-god the teacher ...
Therefore he may take it, the renowned compassionate teacher, (out of) love for us.
May he therefore take it, the renowned compassionate teacher, (out of) love for us.
... with the knowledge belonging to the rank of Buddha: When this cotton cloth will be given to the Community, ...
If this cotton cloth is given to the community, … (Maitreya) will take the cotton cloth, and he will give it as a present to the Buddha, the teacher. (cf 169, slightly different)
... (if) he takes this cotton cloth, he will give it as a present to the Buddha-god the teacher. For this reason, (will) the ... of the noble (Metrak) certainly ...
the thirty-two Lakṣaṇas will in their entirety appear on him. ... the ... of the heir with the rank of a Buddha ...
The thirty-two lakṣaṇas will in their entirety appear on him. (169)
... the Buddha-god the teacher says to queen Gautamī: Gautamī, you (give) this cotton cloth to the Community!
... the Community too will be honored by you. || Having heard that, the queen ...
… the community too will be honored by you. (169)
... I have prepared (this cotton cloth). Why is the Buddha-god the teacher not prepared to accept it from me? Then, ...
… I have prepared (this cotton cloth). Why would the Buddha, the teacher not take it from me?

p.note: This fragment contains part of the third act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; an Uy. parallel is MaitrHami III, 6a20-7a4. See also 196-7.
The translation and the following commentary are adapted from 170.

There are lacunae in the Uyghur text at this point, but the beginning of this leaf corresponds roughly to MaitrHami 3, 6 a21, and its end to 7 a4. TA pälkets is the ﬁrst word of a stanza of the type 20 (5/5/5/5) + 22 (8/7/7) + 10 (5/5) + 15 (8/7).

The pa is last in a ligature; as a form of three syllables is to be expected according to the meter, should a reading (w)paśune be considered? This form would be a variant of opäśśune, and the words opäśśi, opäśśune very characteristically occur in the context of skills. Otherwise, wpäśune* would be the abstract based on a form wpäś* or wpäśi*, which had to be derived from the root wäp- ‘to weave’; in that case, the hypothetic wpäśune should mean ‘art of weaving’.
The verb arṣaṣiññ- is a deadjectival stem comparable to sukaṣiññ- (479). The underlying noun aräṣ* appears to be unknown; is it to be considered a derivation of the stem found in TB ersna ‘shape’?
kantsakarṣnaṃ: a stanza of 4 x 12 (5/7) syllables. For the following discourse, cf. MaitrHami 3, 6 b2ff.
